awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Assembly Mechanisms of Supramolecular Signaling Platforms
awd_abstract_narration:
The numerous reactions that support life must be highly coordinated in the cell to optimize the use of resources and respond to environmental cues.  Isolation of competing processes into distinct sub-cellular organelles minimizes some potential intracellular conflicts.  However, not all sub-cellular organizational units classify as organelles, as they lack a membrane barrier that would define them as such. A newly appreciated organizational unit in the cell is a signaling "hub." Construction of the hub from the ordered assembly of protein building blocks can be triggered by diverse molecular events. This hub, or platform, then recruits additional molecules that initiate the cell's response to the triggers by activating and releasing a downstream signal. The hub both amplifies distress signals and allows for a coordinated response to simultaneous events or insults.  This project aims to establish a framework for understanding how these signal platforms assemble and operate at the molecular level. This information is fundamental to understanding the coordination of the complex network of  cellular processes. The PI directs the Biophysics Research for Baltimore Teens (BRBT) program, an outreach program for which exposes Baltimore city high school students to current research areas. 

Specifically, this project will investigate how supramolecular assemblies mediate stress-response pathways that lead to cell death. The research strategy includes computational methods such as Rosetta and Monte Carlo simulations, Cryo-Electron Microscopy, and quantitative measurements in both cell-free and cell-based systems. The first goal is to determine how different upstream receptors preferentially homo-polymerize, avoid crosstalk, yet recognize a single adaptor assembly. The second goal is to elucidate how different regulators target and inhibit specific signaling components in these pathways. The outcome here will delineate structural and biochemical mechanisms by which supramolecular assemblies coordinate signal integration at different stages of the cell-death pathway.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

The numerous reactions that support life must be highly coordinated in the cell to optimize the use of resources and respond to environmental cues. Isolation of competing processes into distinct sub-cellular compartments not only minimizes any potential conflicts, but also enhances the reaction efficiency. 

 A newly appreciated organizational unit in the cell is a signaling "hub," which are essentially membrane-less-organelle-like supra-structures. Formation of the hub from the ordered assembly of protein building blocks can be triggered by diverse molecular events. This hub, or platform, then recruits additional molecules that initiate the cell's response to the triggers by activating and releasing a downstream signal. The hub both amplifies distress signals and allows for a coordinated response to simultaneous events or insults. 

This project aimed to establish a framework for understanding how these signal platforms assemble and operate at the molecular level in a cell-death pathway triggered by intracellular stresses such as UV-damage and toxic chemicals. 

Outcome of proposed Intellectual merit 

Our research strategy includes computational methods such as Rosetta and Monte Carlo simulations, Cryo-Electron Microscopy, and quantitative measurements in both cell-free and cell-based systems. 

• Using the AIM2 receptor and ASC adaptor in the caspase-1-dependent cell-death pathway, we delineated how similar filamentous supra-structures recognize and distinguish one another (Matyszewski et al. Nat Com, 2021).

• We determine how filament assembly of those that detect dysregulated DNA fragments is coupled to their nucleic acid specificity (e.g., DNA vs. RNA); Garg et al., NAR, 2023

• We elucidated the target specificity and inhibition mechanisms by which pyrin-only-proteins regulate these filamentous assembly (Wu et al., eLife, 2024).

• We determined the cryo-EM structure of IFI16pyrin-domain filament. This work is under minor revision at EMBO J. 

• We also published two method papers arising from our proposed research (Mazanek and Sohn, and Matyszewski and Sohn, both in Methods in Enzymology 2019).

Outcome of proposed Broader Impact 

I have been directing Biophysics Research for Baltimore Teens (BRBT) for 11 years. BRBT is a paid summer research experience program serving high school students from Baltimore City and surrounding counties. To date, we have served more than 100 students. We published our experiences and outcome/impact of this effort (Crews*, Wilson*, Sohn* et al. Tech Learn Med, 2020, * co-first authors).

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/05/2025
Modified by: Jungsan Sohn

Project Outcomes Report


The numerous reactions that support life must be highly coordinated in the cell to optimize the use of resources and respond to environmental cues. Isolation of competing processes into distinct sub-cellular compartments not only minimizes any potential conflicts, but also enhances the reaction efficiency.


A newly appreciated organizational unit in the cell is a signaling "hub," which are essentially membrane-less-organelle-like supra-structures. Formation of the hub from the ordered assembly of protein building blocks can be triggered by diverse molecular events. This hub, or platform, then recruits additional molecules that initiate the cell's response to the triggers by activating and releasing a downstream signal. The hub both amplifies distress signals and allows for a coordinated response to simultaneous events or insults.


This project aimed to establish a framework for understanding how these signal platforms assemble and operate at the molecular level in a cell-death pathway triggered by intracellular stresses such as UV-damage and toxic chemicals.


Outcome of proposed Intellectual merit


Our research strategy includes computational methods such as Rosetta and Monte Carlo simulations, Cryo-Electron Microscopy, and quantitative measurements in both cell-free and cell-based systems.


 Using the AIM2 receptor and ASC adaptor in the caspase-1-dependent cell-death pathway, we delineated how similar filamentous supra-structures recognize and distinguish one another (Matyszewski et al.Nat Com, 2021).


 We determine how filament assembly of those that detect dysregulated DNA fragments is coupled to their nucleic acid specificity (e.g., DNA vs. RNA); Garg et al.,NAR, 2023


 We elucidated the target specificity and inhibition mechanisms by which pyrin-only-proteins regulate these filamentous assembly (Wu et al.,eLife, 2024).


 We determined the cryo-EM structure of IFI16pyrin-domain filament. This work is under minor revision at EMBO J.


 We also published two method papers arising from our proposed research (Mazanek and Sohn, and Matyszewski and Sohn, both inMethods in Enzymology2019).


Outcome of proposed Broader Impact


I have been directing Biophysics Research for Baltimore Teens (BRBT) for 11 years. BRBT is a paid summer research experience program serving high school students from Baltimore City and surrounding counties. To date, we have served more than 100 students. We published our experiences and outcome/impact of this effort (Crews*, Wilson*, Sohn* et al. Tech Learn Med, 2020, * co-first authors).
